low: Small weather changes may slightly stress fish, making them eat a bit less for a short time
Light rain adds a little extra dirt and nutrients from nearby areas to the water
Medium winds can make small waves, briefly lowering oxygen in surface water
Slow temperature changes mildly affect fish energy use and movement
Light clouds block some sunlight gently, slightly slowing algae food production
Small weather shifts may cause minor timing changes in fish breeding activity
high: Severe weather breaks equipment and causes major water quality problems with losses
Extreme storms bring huge amounts of mud and dirt, ruining water quality badly
Strong winds physically hurt fish and damage pond structures severely
Very heavy rain causes nutrient overload, growing dangerous algae that poses health risks
Flooding carries harmful chemicals and sickness-causing agents, spreading disease widely
Sudden severe weather changes shock fish with temperature shifts, causing many deaths and harvest losses
